awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Feedbacks between Orographic Precipitation and Ice Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Aschwanden/1644277

This award supports a project to study the phenomenon of the rain shadow (technically called orographic precipitation) in the Antarctic Peninsula and its interaction with a mountain range covered in ice and snow. Orographic precipitation gives rise to the largest climatic and ecological gradients on Earth.  Air ascending on the windward side of the mountain range expands and cools, condensing the water vapor it carries and producing heavy rain- or snow-fall. As the air descends on the leeward flank, the air warms and dries out, leaving little-to-no precipitation.  This pattern of snowfall, caused by the interaction of winds and the landscape, is hypothesized to control the shape of the ice cap itself. The investigators hypothesize that feedbacks between precipitation and topography control ice flux and temperature, impacting basal conditions (frozen versus wet) and motion, which over long time scales can affect basal topography via erosion.

The authors propose to investigate the feedbacks between orographically driven precipitation, ice dynamics, thermodynamics, and basal erosion and uplift over the northern Antarctic Peninsula by coupling an orographic precipitation model to the Parallel Ice Sheet Model (PISM). Using idealized and more realistic geometries, they will begin with a 2-D flow band model, which will be expanded into three dimensions to determine the strength of the feedbacks as a function of bedrock geometry and the intensity of the orographic precipitation gradient. The Antarctic Peninsula is targeted as the ideal case study, in the context of its rapid modern and future change as well as its deflation since the Last Glacial Maximum.  The broader impacts of the work include the strengthening of predictive models by capturing feedbacks related to orographic precipitation not included in current models. This is likely to provide a more realistic assessment of the impacts of orographic precipitation in a regime of changing climate. The project will support an early career scientist and a female mid-career scientist and will support one PhD student, and provide summer research experience for one undergraduate student as an REU supplement.  The project does not require field work in the Antarctic.

por.por_cntn:
Most mountain ranges have higher rain or snowfall on one side compared to the otherside, usually the high precipitation happens on the ?windward? side or the side that is facing the storms coming off an ocean environment. Familiar examples include the Olympic and Cascades mountains of the Pacific Northwest of North America, the Andes Mountains in South America, the Alps in New Zealand, and the Antarctic Peninsula. This difference in precipitation happens because moist air brought by storms gets pushed upward when it reaches the mountains, and this causes the air to release its moisture as rain or snow. By the time the air reaches the top of the mountain and flows over to the ?leeward? side of the mountain, very little moisture is left, resulting in dry conditions. This process of mountains creating differences in precipitation is called orographic precipitation. This process is a key element of the oft-used phrase  ?the mountain makes its own weather?. 

When the mountain range is in a cold environment and contains glacier ice, the pattern of orographic precipitation causes lots of snowfall on the windward side, growing those glaciers, leaving smaller glaciers on the leeward side. When the glaciers get so big that they cover the peaks of the mountains and become one ?ice cap? covering both sides of the mountain, an unintuitive feedback is triggered that results in bigger glaciers on the leeward side instead of on the windward side. This curious feedback happens because the ice cap is not bounded by the mountain peaks anymore and the high point on the ice (the ?ice divide?) will start to migrate towards the windward direction, this shifts the  flow direction of ice at the highest elevations and causes that ice to flow towards the leeward side of the mountain range. This shift in the ice flow patterns as a result of the orographic precipitation has important implications for both projecting changes in ice cap or ice sheet spatial extent into the near term future and for investigating past glacier extent and erosion rates over the past hundreds of thousands to millions of years. 

The key to understanding and being able to model these past and future dynamic feedbacks requires implementing orographic precipitation physics into our ice sheet models. While such orographic precipitation is rather complex in the real world, scientists have developed a simple model called ?Linear Theory of Orographic Precipitation Model? that does a good job of capturing the basic concept.

For this project, the orographic precipitation model was implemented in the open-source Parallel Ice Sheet Model (PISM), one of the main workhorses for studying glacier change. The coupled model was then applied to study the size and extent of the glaciers of the Olympics Peninsula during the last 125,000 years and the role orographic precipitation plays in the Antarctic Peninsula. In addition, a plugin was developed and released for the popular open-source GIS software ?QGIS? that allows users to study orographic precipitation. We were also able to study some larger concepts in these mountain glacier systems such as the differential erosion of valleys on each side of the mountain range and the development of lateral ice domes when the ice caps extend laterally so much that they trigger a new small ice caps even in places that don?t have a mountain underneath, because the ice reaches a point of creating its own mountains.
